Biosynthesis of <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is predominantly by cells of the monocytic lineage .

This study examined the role of various cis - acting regulatory elements in the lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) induction of the human <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter in cells of monocytic lineage .

text: Functional analysis of monocytic THP-1 cells transfected with plasmids containing various lengths of <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter localized enhancer elements in a region ( -182 to -37 base pairs ( bp ) ) that were required for optimal transcription of the <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in response to LPS .

text: Two regions were identified : region I ( -182 to -162 bp ) contained an overlapping <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> Egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> site , and region II ( -119 to -88 ) contained CRE and NF-kappaB ( designated kappaB3 ) sites .
In unstimulated THP-1 , CRE - binding protein and , to a lesser extent , <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes were found to bind to the CRE site .
LPS stimulation increased the binding of <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - containing complexes .

text: In addition , LPS stimulation induced the binding of cognate nuclear factors to the <extra_id_0> Egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and kappaB3 sites , which were identified as <extra_id_0> Egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , respectively .

text: The CRE and kappaB3 sites in region II together conferred strong LPS responsiveness to a heterologous promoter , whereas individually they failed to provide transcriptional activation .

Furthermore , increasing the spacing between the CRE and the kappaB3 sites completely abolished LPS induction , suggesting a cooperative interaction between <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

These studies indicate that maximal LPS induction of the <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter is mediated by concerted participation of at least two separate cis - acting regulatory elements .
